More flexibility in hours and pay. I would have loved to stay but there was no way for me to go to college while working full time. Had there been a realistic part-time work option, I would have kept working at Vivint. As it stands, though, I would have had to do a full 40 hours worth of units of work in the 20 hours of time I had available - in other words, 0.875 units/hour, or Tier 8 production. During my time there I discovered that people only rarely actually receive a raise for higher tier production despite promises to the contrary (another reason I was dissatisfied), so realistically, I would likely only be paid for Tier 1 or Tier 2 production despite having to do Tier 8 work to keep the job. In other words, I'd be asked to do a full 40 hours of work, in half the time, and for only 20 hours of pay. As this would be a pretty horrible arrangement for me, I decided my best option was to quit and seek other part time work, despite how much I loved my job as a PV designer.

I loved a lot of things about my job at Vivint, and I would love to come back when I am able, but I'll be honest, I will likely apply to competitors first. I loved a lot of things about my job, but the fact that other companies offer a starting pay of $16 an hour for the same position, versus Vivint's $12.50, and that they actually give raises for increased production, unlike Vivint (despite policies to the contrary), makes their offerings a lot more attractive.

I was hired while Sales Process 1.5 was still being used, so I was given the employee handbook for the old system, and the training pay system under that sales process is what I understood and agreed to be what I would be receiving. The week I started was the week Sales Process 2.0 was implemented, and I was not informed of the new training pay system under Sales Process 2.0. In my opinion, the training pay system under Sales process 2.0 makes it nearly impossible to get paid (besides the first payment for generating one lead) until many weeks into training. After the first payment of $750 which is received from generating one lead, in order to receive the next payments you must achieve a welcome call. This essentially means that you have to have a customer agreeing to and signing off on a CAD design for their house by week two, in order to receive consistent pay. This is basically impossible for many reasons. As a new sales rep, you do not have the skills or knowledge to get a customer to the level of understanding and comfort where they are agreeing to a CAD. Also, in general, people need much more time than 2 weeks to make a decision along the lines of putting solar panels on their roof. While nothing is binding until the panels are on the roof, people may be very hesitant to approve anything like a CAD design that quickly. Also, it is often difficult to even schedule a CAD presentation appointment. I generated a lead on my first week, but couldn't even get a CAD presentation scheduled until 4 weeks later. This was just due to the customer being a busy person, but I faced the penalty for it. Overall, I firmly believe the training pay system needs completely restructured. This system does not allow sales reps to support themselves during training, and that is crucial to encouraging employees to stay.

Honestly, there could have been a lot. I think the biggest frustration I had was the training. The training was terrible, and it did not prepare me for the tasks I needed to perform. Out of the entire group I got hired with, there was about 4 or 5 people that lasted. I'm surprised I lasted the time I did. While I had worked there, I had so many questions that my managers would be annoyed and would treat me as inferior because of my questions. I didn't like that the managers would play favorites...If my co-worker had a question, they would simply answer it...If I had a questions, that would treat me like an idiot, as if I SHOULD know what the answer was. They would always respond in a rhetorical question such as, "Well what do YOU think the answer is??" But yeah, the training was lack luster at best. I mean, they did a good job on letting us know what the Solar products do, but for every 7 phone calls out of 10 there would be a customer calling with a question that I have never been trained on...a lot of times I was accidentally giving out false information simply because of the lack of training and knowledge. The other thing I didn't like was that the job was not very flexible. Every 2 weeks you would get 3 whole hours of time off. As someone who has another job that requires me to travel, it made it nearly impossible to live outside of work...it just felt like I was a slave there. Anyways, to sum it all up as the reasons why I left: 1 - Lack of training, 2 - Poor management and leadership skills, 3 - lack of flexibility to get time off. \\I did like the food though. I definitely miss the sushi there.

It is difficult to say what lead to my termination, but there are several observations I would like to share.\1. Management at the Santa Fe office definitely is outstanding in all areas pertaining to sales. On the other hand, they know very little about operational aspects of running an office and people management.\2. There is little or no communication between the managers on important subject matters. The lead manager, in my case, was not aware that I was terminated by another manager. Another example, with my superior knowledge in all aspects relating to solar energy and solar installations, I approached the lead manager and offered to bring a representative for Owens Corning roofing materials to teach the sales team everything about roofing. The lead manager was enthusiastic about the opportunity to teach the sales staff about roofs and seconded my effort. On the day of the presentation he was not present and another manager was in charge. This manger had not been briefed, even though the topic was mentioned in two meetings and staff was encouraged to attend the training session. The manager had different plans for the meeting and completely ignored the Owens Corning representative for over one hour. My efforts to correct this were rudely dismissed. Finally the manager spoke to the rep from Owens Corning and told him that everyone in the sales team knows about roofs and that he was not needed. Not only was this extremely rude towards the Owens Corning rep who just wasted two hours of his time, it was also untrue that sales staff know all about roofs because most of the staff had been on board for only a few weeks.\3. Considering the requirement of using computer programs designed exclusively for the Apple operating system, Vivint should be able to assist those employees without Apple devices to acquire such at reduced rates. Vivint employs a huge sales force and would be in a position to negotiate excellent terms with Apple. I don't have an I-Pad and do not have a budget to readily purchase one. Management should be in a position to arrange for people like me to obtain an I-Pad either by loaning a company I-Pad or by tapping into Vivint resources to make it possible for the sales rep to work properly and efficiently. Because of my inability to close my generated leads, I had a very poor performance. The causality between the two was known to management.

I have no yet decided on a new company and I regret having been terminated by my office. However, I will be looking for a company that offers a base salary and, should that be required, the necessary tools for me to execute my work. \Incidentally, the $ 6,000 sign up Vivint bonus is misleading on several levels and has been criticized by many in the sales staff. If Vivint wants to retain top representatives, Vivint should focus more on fairness and respect. If not, Vivint will burn through a lot of talent. In the short term the present approach might be successful, but in the long run it will fail. The solar market is becoming increasingly competitive and that spells trouble for companies focusing on short term gain. Ultimately shareholder value will be affected too.

Matt Jackson is unfit for any supervisory role whatsoever. He creates a negative work environment with threats. He takes out his stress and his own inadequacies on employees around him. He acts as if he has no managerial experience whatsoever in dealing with crew. Unprofessional, abusive, racist, sexist, poor morals, poor ethics, uncaring attitude. He simply tells his bosses whatever they want to hear and takes out his shortcomings on crews who are overworked already.\Corey Phelps is a crew lead who recently moved from Albuquerque to the recently reopened Hawaii location, he is equally abusive, domineering, has anger management issues, and, although I believe he is not in a supervisory role any longer he should not be allowed back into that position due to his threatening and unsafe work practices.\Both individuals are pushing unsafe work practices by putting up an illusion of conforming with safety standards only when the safety inspector for the company, Michael Kennerson is in town. Crew leads have set up a private chat app with other crew leads across the country with Vivint solar employees to warn others when the safety inspector is in town. They force crews to work through unsafe conditions such as high wind speeds, rain, lightning, excessive heat With No Breaks Allowed, and other safety conditions in which company standards would not allow us to work on that rooftop. OSHA requires access to a restroom such as a porta potty on each job site, we never had one on any of our job sites. Even though we were told not to, we are forced to urinate in bottles in the back of the company truck in order to not offend the customer buy them seeing us urinating Outdoors. You are expected to drive the company truck to a restroom at a gas station miles away if you need other facilities. Anchors for safety ropes are installed for looks and not into studs as required. This is due to pressure by the company to hurry up and get the job done. Putting up safety ropes and taking them down takes more than an hour sometimes which the bosses would not allow. On tile roofs, Anchor Points are not sealed according to Rocky's standards. They think it takes too long. They just fill the holes in with sealant and reinstall the anchor bolts. They say this is good enough. They forced us to carry extremely heavy items such as solar panels up ladders up to three stories tall, claiming safer methods take too long. We do not have Skylight guards in our warehouse even though it is company policy to install those on each skylight, never seen one, seen dozens of skylights though. We install on roof pitches that are Beyond the company's safety standards, too steep. We install panels on rooftops that have shading issues when there is plenty of space in the yard for a pole mount system with no shading issues. Solar panel should not be installed on roofs with any shading issues, that shows me the salesmen are just being greedy. They are also being pressured from the top to sell any job no matter what the cost, we install on unsafe rotting rooftops, then we get sued for leaks and take more than a year to fix it, all of this from pressure from the top to make sales with no concern for installing solar correctly. It is all about the numbers increasing. Forcing two and sometimes three jobs per day is unsafe and not fair to the customer for a quality installation. Vivint solar is being sued in New Mexico and multiple States for damage to homes and rooftops where solar panel should never have been installed in the first place. Salesman are threatened to sell anything or risk being fired, crews compete with productivity numbers to see who is the fastest with no concern for safety, quality, or or building a photovoltaic system the way you would want one installed on your house. I believe all of this and Vivnt's negative image to the public are contributing to the downfall of photovoltaic sales from other, good companies.  People want solar but they don't want Vivint to come and ruin their house and not fix it fast enough. They want to feed back into the grid andpay off their panels and own them. Vivint can't do that. They want to have solar power when the grid is down, Vivint can't do that. They want a pole mount array out in their yard and not damage their nice roof, Vivint can't do that. Customers I have talked to said Vivint put leaks in the roof, gave them a second power bill, and they pay the same for electricity they paid before, now they just have to pay it to two different places. Vivint installs all Chinese products. This is bad for the United States economy. Vivint solar has proven to me that it is more concerned with profit then it is with photovoltaics and the health and safety of its employees.

When I worked there; it was a hand to mouth existence. You were dealing with high stress costumers, work challenges and no pay. This was not what I would say is a good mix, in fact it is a recipe for disaster. No one likes to have high pressure miserable job, then not get paid for it. So the change I would suggest, is create a way for your new employee's to stick around long enough to gain the skills necessary to succeed. I realize that it isn't as cost effective to pay your new sales agents in order to get them by. However, what kind of culture are you trying to create. Do you want all your new employees to stick around and not be in fear of if they are going to make rent; or do you want to create a supporting environment in which you foster talent long enough to become fully mature. I hope for the sake of the organization you get it figured out.

After careful thought and consideration, I have concluded that my core values are not aligned with the organizational "culture" at Vivint Solar. It is time to move on to maintain my health, sanity, and overall happiness. This letter is to officially inform you that I resign from my position as a Warehouse Lead and Warehouse Specialist immediately. This letter also serves as my exit interview. The biggest challenge at Vivint Solar would stem from a lack of effective systems. However, I quickly realized that inflated egos, office politics, and administrative incompetence would prove to be bigger obstacles. These dynamics were not conducive to productivity. I was deprived of a heathy work and life balance. I did not receive fair gratitude for the work I was held accountable for by myself, even after going above and beyond what was required from a Warehouse Lead/Warehouse Specialist while still maintaining optimal statistics. Additionally, I have been reprimanded and questioned from management above my Supervisor. False claims were made regarding my work performance. I hardly think that a statement from one person that can not execute any position under himself, constitutes a concrete fact. Once it was admitted that the idea of promoting was only being held over my head, I left because I absolutely refuse to promote under such selfish and close minded ignorance. Without vision, there is no successful outcome. My future means more to me than to deal with any person of higher management that is Ignoramus. Nevertheless, from the time I transferred from Operations to Supply Chain, my immediate supervisor has been nothing but helpful and supportive. Without his help, I would have never been this longstanding. Fortunately for me, I know my worth and I am very well aware of the value I bring to a team. I refuse to settle for any form of disrespect, particularly from individuals whose only credibility resides in their job title as opposed to demonstrated excellence and leadership. I’m positive my experience isn’t an isolated one. The lack of employee engagement and satisfaction are enough evidence of to prove the inability to attract, create, and retain talent. Let it be known that my goal was to run with this company as it was the first job I obtained out of college. Unfortunately, it became abundantly clear to me that my integrity would be pushed to the edge, due to the unethical circumstances I endured with the overlooked and prolonged overtime. I could continue to share more for the purposes of an exit interview, but I have little faith that information gathered would be compiled to formulate a retention strategy. Please let me know what to expect as far as my paid time off and my employee benefits. IF I can be of assistance during this immediate transition, Xtisin Denney may contact me. For the last time, please accept this message as notification that I am resigning from Vivint Solar, Tuesday, June 27th 2017. Sincerely, Curtis Hager
Support inside of the warehouse in order to have a healthy work and life balance. Instead, I was working 80-85 hours which forced me to hate a job I once loved

After careful thought and consideration, I have concluded that my core values are not aligned with the organizational "culture" at Vivint Solar. It is time to move on to maintain my health, sanity, and overall happiness. This letter is to officially inform you that I resign from my position as a Warehouse Lead and Warehouse Specialist immediately. This letter also serves as my exit interview. The biggest challenge at Vivint Solar would stem from a lack of effective systems. However, I quickly realized that inflated egos, office politics, and administrative incompetence would prove to be bigger obstacles. These dynamics were not conducive to productivity. I was deprived of a heathy work and life balance. I did not receive fair gratitude for the work I was held accountable for by myself, even after going above and beyond what was required from a Warehouse Lead/Warehouse Specialist while still maintaining optimal statistics. Additionally, I have been reprimanded and questioned from management above my Supervisor. False claims were made regarding my work performance. I hardly think that a statement from one person that can not execute any position under himself, constitutes a concrete fact. Once it was admitted that the idea of promoting was only being held over my head, I left because I absolutely refuse to promote under such selfish and close minded ignorance. Without vision, there is no successful outcome. My future means more to me than to deal with any person of higher management that is Ignoramus. Nevertheless, from the time I transferred from Operations to Supply Chain, my immediate supervisor has been nothing but helpful and supportive. Without his help, I would have never been this longstanding. Fortunately for me, I know my worth and I am very well aware of the value I bring to a team. I refuse to settle for any form of disrespect, particularly from individuals whose only credibility resides in their job title as opposed to demonstrated excellence and leadership. I’m positive my experience isn’t an isolated one. The lack of employee engagement and satisfaction are enough evidence of to prove the inability to attract, create, and retain talent. Let it be known that my goal was to run with this company as it was the first job I obtained out of college. Unfortunately, it became abundantly clear to me that my integrity would be pushed to the edge, due to the unethical circumstances I endured with the overlooked and prolonged overtime. I could continue to share more for the purposes of an exit interview, but I have little faith that information gathered would be compiled to formulate a retention strategy. Please let me know what to expect as far as my paid time off and my employee benefits. IF I can be of assistance during this immediate transition, Xtisin Denney may contact me. For the last time, please accept this message as notification that I am resigning from Vivint Solar, Tuesday, June 27th 2017. Sincerely, Curtis Hager

I worked there for 3 years. When i started there it was $10.50/hour, in that first year i worked really hard to earn my raises, about the time i got to $12.50/hour we changed the base pay up to 12.50 starting. This was a bit frustrating for me because i had worked hard to make earn more. After a month or so i decided that i would just have to earn those raises again. At this point i had worked in 7 different offices including Piloting Arizona, the commercial solar project and san diego (at the time the largest and most difficult) trained 8 new designers 4 of which went on to be leads and 1 to be supervisor, was nominated for employee of the month 3 times and for the BAD CAD award twice (which doesnt exist anymore but was an award for a design with the most modules and difficulty of house). I had applied for multiple lead positions but in the end would be passed up, twice just due to scheduling issues. Then after 3 years and for most of this was going out of my way to aid the department (especially training) and in 3 years i recieved 0 compensation or even notice, and even with recomendations from leads and supervisors there was no compensation. In tandum they ruined scheduling which forced me to do full time work and full time school, eventually i became too stressed to function well in either. So i decided to leave. I have always supported Vivint solar and still do. The company is moving forward and making good progress, not perfect but good. It seems to me that certain people or positions in the company head are loosing site of who was really keeping them up there. There just seemed to be a lack of care, all replaced with neglect.
I left vivint for school. The reward is higher and the future brighter.

When I started, there was a lot of talk about autonomy, we would be allowed to do what we want between calls when the call flow was slow, things like listen to music, watch Netflix, etc. as long as it didn't interfere with calls. Soon after, that was not the case anymore. The longer I was employed, the less autonomy I had, and the more my time was micro-managed. If i had a question, I could reach out through chat or ask in person and get an answer within a few seconds, then the policy changed, we couldn't ask questions in the chat, we couldn't ask our colleagues in the chat, we had to call the team lead line. When we have meetings saying, "we're starting to use NPS and we want to have really good scores" but when the changes made and still being made are making things worse for the customer experience, when we process a work order that has to go to tier 2, but something in it wasn't done perfectly, and the customer calls back weeks later because their work order was never scheduled, and we see that tier 2 said something was missing and did nothing about it, didn't send an email, didn't assign it to the person who created it, literally notated that they can't do it because something was missing...how is that better for the customer? How is that going to get us better NPS scores than 0? When I have 0 power to do anything for a customer, where I can't promise anything, whether it can clearly be seen that they were over billed, or their system is on fire, I can't promise that we will compensate them or that a technician will actually show up for an appointment. When technicians show up to an appointment and don't even get out of their van before they leave and say they weren't able to do the work, all of these things happen often, and all of these things are completely unacceptable. What's also unacceptable is the Power Purchase Agreement; this is literally a scam for the customers. We put a system on their home that will produce more power than they use, and they get billed for all of it, plus a bill from their local utility company? How is this not a scam? On top of that, it goes up by almost 2% every year? That means that within 5 years, the per kWh charge they are billed at will be the same as or more than the utility companies kWh charge. I couldn't continue working for a company that claims they are saving customers money, claim to be a good thing for their customers, but is not that. The shady, underhanded nature of the business is a big part of why i couldn't maintain my employment at Vivint Solar.

My direct manager is a great person, but the individual my manager reported to was extremely difficult. Changing and unrealistic expectations and ongoing miscommunications from the top down made my life and my team's life hell, and my manager started to become difficult as he/she tried to manage all the ridiculous expectations. I wish collaboration was something that happened, rather than something that we said was happening. I wish I could have trusted my leaders and that my ideas were valued. I wish that I woke up excited to go to work each day instead of waking up to dread my day because I had no idea what new crazy thing was going to come my way.

Great leadership. My manager has a clear direction for our department, and the entire company is on the same page as far as goals and progress. I didn't know that was possible, and it's really an amazing feeling to come to work every day and work towards challenging, yet, achievable goals.\They also have offered me pay that I deserve and an opportunity to grow. After a certain point with Vivint Solar, my qualifications were discredited and I was denied raises even though I threatened to leave because my pay was too low. I know that if I were to approach my manager here and discuss my financial situation with him, my concerns would be heard and my needs would be met because I am valued as an employee. I am not one to simply ask for money because I want it; I ask for it because it is an absolute necessity and I know that I deserve it. Being denied financial stability is humiliating, especially when I am forced to beg.
Please, please, please... Notice your employees and reward those that deserve it so you don't lose the ones that you truly need. Find your faults as leaders and decide to work on them.

I was paid less than my counterparts reporting to the same manager but my performance was always above expectations. I was also paid anywhere from 10% to 20% less than my counterparts. At one point I asked for a raise and was told that my department did not grant raises unless it was during the annual review process. Two weeks later two people in the same organization received raises. I waited for the annual review process and did get a 25% raise but it was then at the 10% to 20% below my peers. \\The other problem I had with Vivint Solar was the way different departments were treated. Sales and Operations (Install) could spend money on all kinds of parties, trips, etc.. I took my team out for a lunch to a fast food restaurant for a birthday and was told it was excessive spending. For 6 of us the total cost was under $50. At the same time a Sales group took their whole team out to a steak dinner with alcohol and rented limo for the entire group with a plus 1. Then they rented out a night club after that spending over $9K and those expenses were approved.\\Also during the holidays the CFO sent out an email to all managers explaining instead of a corporate Holiday party we would have small department parties for less than $25 per person. Later we saw the executives went out for their Holiday party and took a plus 1 and spent hundreds per person. This is just one of many examples of how upper management does not practice what they preach.\\I don't understand why the Sales group is not held accountable for the decisions that they make. They spend in excess proven by their CPW going up over the past two years as the rest of the company CPW has gone down. But they still continue to be rewarded for their lack of performance and get to go on the Megawatt trip every year. Why not reward some of the higher performers at corporate with the Megawatt trip too? An example of their performance going down can be seen in the MW installed over Q2 and Q3 this year as we had our worst month in over 3 years in July. This is all when the sales force has increased this year exponentially. \\It also appeared that upper management would hire friends rather than those who were better qualified. This again can mostly be seen in the sales and install organization but the accounting organization brought in many friends and thus limited opportunities to those outside that group. I feel that accounting is finally getting to a point where there are some of those opportunities but know others don't feel the same about some other groups.\\We also did not get support from upper management on items outside the policy that they didn't follow or certain groups didn't follow see again the holiday parties or employees submitting expense reports that had items that were outside the company policy. \\There was no communication between upper management and my team. My boss had a director meeting with his boss weekly. Not once in my four years there was anything in that meeting discussed with me or my team. No updates on items, or things to improve or look for.

If you want to keep hiring high school (and some college) graduates and non-graduates then keep offering zero benefits and no base pay. Training should ALWAYS have base pay, not a lot of people that survive on their own can commit to potentially 1-2 months without pay. Once a salesman is up and running then switch them to just commission, but offer base (even minimum) hourly wages during training until the salesman's commission is check is higher than their hourly. Also, it is 2017... You expect salesman to buy their own ipad, which they HAVE to use during the sales AND you don't offer benefits... You will only have half-ass salesman that only know how to push people into a sale, rather than work with customers to make the best sale for them, when you offer NOTHING upfront. FYI Vivint, there are better products and markets for salesman to make more money without walking door-to-door on Saturdays. Make it more appealing to quality salesman with different types of sales people, more benefits, and more product offerings.

Worked for Vivint Solar for close to 4 years and was an extremely successful District Survey Supervisor. I was a multiple recipient of top performer awards, elite operations winner, I trained multiple managers, created new innovative reporting structures and reporting sheets that were used to successfully improve my state and my regions KPIS and metrics monitoring. I was a part of the incentive build out program to generate new innovative goals and rewards to push department production. Received multiple recommendation letters from District Sales Managers, Operations managers, and Regional Operations Managers for a role to progress into a Regional Management role. I not once received a raise in my role as a District Manager, regardless of my performance. Personally felt that the department director was a poor leader that allowed pressure of senior management to be taken out on his teams. Since coming into the role we eliminated all previous incentive programs, due to lack of continuing to keep up with the metrics monitoring. Top performance metrics were never accurate 'The League'. Even after multiple District supervisors and Regional Managers investigated the discrepancies in the metrics nothing was ever changed. The director even became angry for looking into the reporting and numbers being pulled, "because no one had asked me / us to do so." The district managers and surveyors were held to a completely un-obtainable metric standard that left the west coast at an impossible to overcome advantage. The same District Supervisor won the top performance award repeatedly even after the discrepancies were identified. He showed a complete disregard for field surveyors, by having performance metrics based of technician tiers that he had no idea how or where the tiers were created. A tier was supposed to be based on either time with company and pay or pay rate. However a Tech 1 that made $15 an hour in one state, where a tech in another state was making $23 and was labeled a Tech 1 in another.  Tier rates were supposed to hold techs accountable for production rates. Multiple techs were improperly labeled which prevented the techs from being able to receive compensation increases. Again, this WAS brought to his attention and nothing was done about it. This FORCED multiple team members to quit due to unfair compensation and unfair opportunity to advance. From the moment Andy Moore took over the Survey Department, team morale plummeted. There was no regard for team members in the field and his team of managers. The only thing that kept people around were the regional managers who were shunned if the brought anything up that was different from his way of thinking. It was a terrible feeling to have to leave a department that I had invested almost 4 years into, and helped grow with the original director Jason Anderson and then watch it get turned inside out by poor leadership. I was let go by because of a reduction in force due to a write up that was on my record that was over a year old and was told that it had been expunged. Though I was the most senior and highest performing District Managers in my department, I was let go because I had a write up that was over a year old. My replacement had been in his role (and trained by me) for less than 6 months... This was a complete abandonment by a company I dedicated myself too.Truly could not believe it. I hope that Vivint Solar finds a better way to appreciate and recognize those who are passionate about what they do and those who consistently go above and beyond. I hope that they take the time to realize how detrimental their current leadership has been towards not just their metrics, but the employees and their morale. When the company started, they cared about the individuals, and the company was employee centered. Andy ruined that mentality due to inability to lead and motivate his team, accept new ideas and welcome constructive criticism,  and improperly taking his frustration out on his team when his leadership put pressure on him.  Example: Evan wanted to know why surveyors weren't hitting their KPI's, but instead of Andy allowing his team to explain the logical reason or inaccuracy of the data, he refuted what they would say or refuse to hear explanation and would threaten disciplinary action..\\I truly hope that someone takes the time to read this and passes it to Evan or Paul. This is truly terrible what has and is happening in this organization. Techs and managers deserve better or it will continue to run down hill.

Higher salary, career growth opportunity, and above all else, senior management team who cares about the tech's and supervisors and allows everyone an equal opportunity. They are not run like a dictatorship and allow everyone to have a voice.

I just want to explain that I didn’t willingly leave Vivint Solar. What I am about to explain has nothing to do with Vivint Solar as a company but about operations management of NJ-06. \\My time with the company I loved. I moved up from installer to lead to foreman within 7months. Vivint Solar treats their employees pretty well. However, based on the OM I was fired for being late quite often. Being that everyone was also always late, I sense there was a deeper motive to why I was actually fired. I understood Vivint Solar’s policies to tardiness, which doesn’t change anything. However, I still showed up every day. There have been employees who have done “no call no shows” quite often. Yet not one of them have received any consequences. Favoritism was an obvious trate. When given the foreman position I never complained when I was given $24hr, when in fact we were told foreman’s made nothing less than $27.50hr. I still didn’t complain when the ground electrician on my crew was given a raise at $24hr. As a foreman I probably should have been upset that someone on my crew was making the same as me while I was doing a lot of the heavy lifting. But that would be unethical. \\Lack of understanding the teams concerns and needs was also careless and brushed off. Aggressive words, threats of laying off employers or deducting their hours, and profanity were often used when crews were unable to fully complete an install and/or when an entire crew felt unsafe. Write ups were falsified and stored to instill fear in employers. Which would then only get submitted when employees could not complete an install.\\ Many reason’s to why an employee would want to leave a company. But in my case the company was great to me, the OM was not.
Set hours. Making sure employers are at the shop no later then 5p

Overall it felt like management actively hid information from lower end reps for success. I was reprimanded for trying to teach our team which roofs to avoid (ones Vivint panels are incapable of being mounted upon) which would have retained a lot of people who left over disappointments over these roofs. The upper management in charge of Structural Holds had no actual experience in roofing nor construction, and was incompetent at accessing jobs accurately....he refused to remove a hold on our largest job despite it being shown the Hold was mos attributed. This costs the company $$$...and employees who aren’t paid on jobs that cannot go forward
Many different mounting systems, panel manufacturers and competent contractors(installers with experience and proper licensing that don’t botch jobs)

If management would stop running the office like one big frat party! They discriminate against women and set you up for failure, it seems to only make their quota. I was locked in to an area by the local college where there were 90% of the current residents were students and retiree's well past their 60's, & on a fixed income. The managers start off extremely harsh by down grading women verbally in front of all the guys. I was even referred to as Donahue instead of Donna, then was told a laughing "sorry." Then they spend company time doing guy things, like going to the local gun shooting range, without asking the women. This is all geared around deliver making you feel unwanted. People come on randomly late with lame excuses but it's ok depending on weather your male or female. Females get ridiculed on the spot and sent threatening email warnings of possible pending termination. Guys come in late and it's an oh that's ok. New hires men get treated with the upmost respect and offered all the onboarding details, I myself had to keep asking questions. I was talked down to like a 5 year old, so I stopped asking. I kept calling experienced co-workers to go out with them and got the run around. So I went out with the assistant manager only to be talked to worse than a dog, and scolded to never say a word when your shadowing. He later apologized. The clients wife asked me a simple question of what happens if someone dies...I mentioned no problem things would transfer over. I guess it was wrong and I needed to be harshly reprimanded. No one bothered to go over my pitch until weeks into it. Then my iPad was erased by the assistant manager, knowing that I didn't have the ability to upgrade the app. My app was continuously shut off in Doors, I kept calling the help line and The kept saying that I didn't have a home office. So as I door knocked it made it different to do my job. Newly hired guys had no issues with Doors. The final straw was when I was last to be told how to apply to get company shirts and apparel and was never told about the reimbursement that I was owed by passing my exam, whereupon I had to buy my own Home Improvement Book online simply because I was told by the lead manager repeatedly that I didn't need to worry about taking my test. I order the book after finding out that those hired after me, had their books the same week to study for. I was sent a group text  by both managers whom are best friends, how did I do on my state exam? They assumed o failed. I passed! I was hindered in every way then threatened that if o didn't have 5 sales by a certain date I would be fired! Needless to say i sent for my license at their office and the secretary said that she processed it and that it would take around 2 weeks or so. I kept calling the main office that handled that and they said they knew nothing. I called The Dept of Labor and they never received my application that I had signed by both the manager and assistant manager. I have them a few choice words after taking to another female that recently was let go for not making her quota. I found out through her that we had a deadline on making a certain amount of sales, something the head managers should have informed me about. New hired that were there were helped with their pitch one on one, I later complained and sent my own pitch via cell phone recording and was ridiculously ridiculed. I let another experiences solar sales guy listen and he said it wasn't so bad. These two managers in my opinion do not need to work in the same office. I now work for a different solar company and would highly recommend Vivint Solar because they run a top company. I just wouldn't recommend going to the Delmar Office if your a female. Total discrimination. I left these two managers with some harsh choice words of my own, including how they set me up for failure and that was out of character for me, and I felt they deserved it. They even asked those who came to check out the job offer, "If you had an athelete that you would choose to have a man crush on, who would it be?" Well, those two guys never came back after that awkward moment. Why would a head manager ask that? I hope this helps someone. I wasn't going to say anything, but if this testimony can help the next woman or man that's not into the whole frat like fiasco and antics on the job...then I have done my job. Once other male co-workers see how your being disrespected they to stay away from you, as if your poison, from all the negative back biting insults. There is too much favoritism as far as which areas consultants are assigned to, as far as the others, well expect to be locked into an area where they already know won't be productive. Again, I never got my license from them, after all the run around and head games. The End. Such a great company with poor money hungry managers, that want sales but set certain people up for failure. How do you fix something that they would never admit to. Don't take my word for it, check to see how many times I had contacted technical support, only to find out it was because I hadn't scheduled my exam in which the head boss said I didn't need to worry about??? Most of these guys failed their exam on the first try, I can say I still felt like a winner! No sales but the odds were against me from day one. Sad to witness. Sad to say. This is my truth. When other females excelled with the company, remarks were made like, "oh they are successful only because they feel sorry for them and give them leads." It was not a good environment for me. It's a male dominated job but no one should be treated in such a demeaning way. No one. DP

The direction they were going in the design department was away from human talent and toward automation and subdividing functions of design to different teams so that you can hire anyone to do those functions. There were essentially no standards except output of number of designs. The productivity requirements were ridiculous. The possibility of a raise kept getting moved further away. Upper management kept getting stricter about things that were completely unimportant and damaging to morale. To make it the kind of place to stay at long term you need to fire the head of the design department and change some basic cultural aspects of what you expect from the designers and provide a pathway of advancement that isn't based on moving them into management positions. The metrics you measured to gauge the value of your employees encouraged people to game your systems and drove quality lower. I abandoned the green energy field entirely because of working at Vivint Solar. Maybe you can't afford to treat your designers like skilled labor. Designer wages for green energy are pretty lousy in general so maybe you are normal for your field.

Well for starters, maybe if the upper management (the people making the decisions) knew, or cared, how their decisions affect the real people at the bottom *doing all of the work.*\\After nearly a year and a half of working at VSLR it became very clear to me that all they see is $ dollar signs $ and not people.  They make changes in our process that benefit the company, but ignore the very real negative affect it has on THE PEOPLE who are actually doing the work that makes them money.  Remember, without designers, you get no designs, and thus make no money.  So treat your employees with respect, right?  Seems obvious to me, but apparently not to them.\\I say that because from literally day 1 they started arbitrarily raising requirements.  First they bumped the minimum production to 3 points.  Sure, that's achievable, so whatever, I kept going.  Then they raised it to 3.5 points, which is, depending on how lucky you are with the accounts you pull, arguably much more difficult to achieve for your average designer.  And forget about achieving tier 2 or above.  Especially because if you make mistakes on designs EVER, that essentially bars you from getting a raise (95% accuracy required or no raise at all).\\It just seems to me that the management was doing everything in their power to stop designers from getting raises, to block us from advancing in the company.  That's not a healthy business practice.  Because people know their worth, and they know that they deserve better treatment than that.  So if your company continues to treat their designers poorly, if they continue to pile more and more work on to the design team without EVER compensating them with more pay, people WILL quit and find different jobs.\\Sure, you can hire more people.  But if you think you can turn n burn through new employees like Vivint inc. does, you'll be sorely disappointed.  It takes a good 4-6 MONTHS for a new designer to be able to produce the MINIMUM stats required by management.  If you really think that forcing all of your good designers out and replacing them with new people will accomplish anything, you're wrong.  Especially because the training was basically non-existent.  How do you expect new people to accomplish anything without training?\\So, in short, this company's business practice is purely illogical and greed based.  You may be able to stay afloat for a while by exploiting your employees, but it will only take you so far before people grow weary of being mistreated and leave.  Then what?

Well for starters they respect me, they appreciate the hard work that I do, and they don't constantly throw more work at me without compensating me with more pay.  More work = more pay.  That's how it works in the real world.  You don't get to just force people to keep taking on more responsibility without giving them more in return.
Lots of people in the department felt/feel the same way as I do.

You really need to treat your design department better.  I know that it's a team effort and that without any one of the departments it all falls apart.  But seriously, Design is the work horse of the company and it seems like they just get punished every time any thing goes wrong, even if it's not their fault.  Like for example, the company issued a sales incentive for the sales reps, to get them to sell more.  As a result, we had extremely large back logs that kept growing no matter how much we chipped away at it.  And because of this, you started issuing MANDATORY OVERTIME for your DESIGNERS.  You PUNISHED us purely because of your sales incentive, not because of anything that we did wrong.  There are other examples of this practice that happened during my time there.  You need to quit doing that otherwise you won't have any designers before long.

Mainly the training. They need to improve and have a program for their training. I didn't like it because every manger was putting his point of view on the training. Nobody wanted to hear it. Everyone including managers have to sell or sink so taking time to train new reps would cost managers thousands of dollars a month in salary and a loss of competition status because their number of installs would be smaller.

What was passed as “training” was more motivational than substance. The training for new recruits on how to present information successfully on a customers doorstep was excellent. The failure was not teaching recruits how to use and be comfortable with the many company specific apps, most notably NEO since that’s what has to be done right to seal the contract.

Better training on the software and apps that are required to seal contracts and therefor get paid. Vivint offers the best pay structure I have ever seen and I’ve seen my share. At 47 years old I’ve done this type of work for decades before some of these reps were born. Lol. I’ve even been a District Manager for a Fortune 500 insurance company. You guys have a great system for Pay and other rewards for those who work hard. The disconnect is when your reps run into a legit buyer who’s interested and the deal falls apart when they fumble through NEO because there is no mechanism like a “training mode” option. Even if it wasn’t a traditional classroom style learning scenario, if your software guys could just ad a “training mode” tab where reps could practice at home etc that would be a huge huge positive step.

Nobody wanted to hear it. Everyone including managers have to sell or sink so taking time to train new reps would cost managers thousands of dollars a month in salary and a loss of competition status because their number of installs would be smaller.

The biggest thing is getting the new reps trained on NEO and other apps to a certain proficiency level before turning them loose to sell and subjecting them to accountability for production. This causes huge stress and anxiety especially for the young guys. Second, I’d say the management positions, what’s expected of them, needs to be totally overhauled. If a working DM spends 2 hrs a week doing hands on training they are never going to win any of the sales contests and would probably lose 1-2 deals per month just for lack of available hours in their day. That equates to probably a $3k-$5k loss every month and that’s just on the front end, not counting the detriment to their overall numbers for quarterly bonus incentives. Third, all these reps are 1099 employees and Vivint has probably one of the cheapest employee overhead costs of any company in the direct sales industry. So the question is, who cares if a rep sells 2 deals a month or 10? People in general are already self motivated by a larger paycheck to attempt to get as many deals as they can and for some people it takes longer than others to get up to speed. But if that person is not a problem employee and is working on increasing production why keep threatening to fire them if they don’t produce more? If I hadn’t quit I would have been fired for underproduction. In fact I was booted out of NEO and my email was closed before anyone told me the door was closing for me at Vivint. And to this day I have never been officially notified of anything relating to the circumstances of my departure with the exception of this post employment survey today. I wish I was still working for Vivint but I was pushed out by my DM, corporate or both I have no idea. In summary Pay and opportunity are great. Site management procedures need a total revamp. Training on Vivint specific software and apps is horrible to non existent.

I was a very good employee and would have been a supervisor if I had stayed. I decided to go back to school at the University of Utah to finish my Electrical engineering degree. I asked to lower my hours I needed to work in order to be successful in school which they were willing to do since I was an exceptional employee. I was very transparent with my plans with management and was hoping to use my degree to help Vivint solar be more stable and organized as the electrical engineering department always seemed swamped and the current electrical engineer is not happy with the work load to the point he has wanted to quit several times. I asked to only drop my hours during the semester and would be more than happy to work full time when I wasn't in school \\Although I gave my all to Vivint Solar and stayed over night and worked voluntary overtime to help my team succeed and the company meet their goals. Management decided to tell me that I needed to produce full time numbers while working part time or they would have to let me go, they gave me less than a half weeks warning for this. I did not appreciate the short notice as I have always been respectful and given more than 2 weeks notice of my plans with the company, I believe 2 weeks should have been given as that is what you expect from your employees. \\The pay was ok but should have been higher as Vivint Solar is the lowest in the industry. What was more frustrating was being promised a raise and then never seeing it come to fruition. I was around during the sun edison "merger" and we were promised if we did so much work and gained so much experience  we would be "CAD Tech 2" and get a raise. Obviously the Merger fell through and the raises never happened which is fine the thing that bugged me the most is no one ever explained what happened or that we weren't getting raises they simply never talked about it which is terrible management and leadership in my opinion. And honestly that is one example of hundreds of examples of poor management and leadership.\\ I think many of the persons in management are very under-qualified for their position an were hired solely based on friendships with managers, which is sad but true. One example of this is when John Hard hired Cameron Snyder. This was a disaster he had no idea what he was doing and I heard he said he wanted to fire someone who didn't come in to work a mandatory shift to create an example of them. Great managers lead by example and find the tools necessary to make their employees and company succeed, I believe Cameron was on a power trip with poor management skills and did not have the technical skills necessary to understand the business. Don't get me wrong I like Cameron as a person and was actually his 2nd pick to become a supervisor, I merely bring this up to show that he wasn't a good fit and was chosen by John Hard because he was friends with him at Dish Network. Two other current supervisors where promoted at the same time one would sleep under his desk during work a week after I caught this individual doing this he was promoted. Another person that was promoted I would say was at his desk 30% of the time it got so bad that people from his team would come ask me design questions and I would answer probably 80% of their phone calls because he wasn't at his desk working. \\John Hard I think did a good job with the business and analytical part of the business but I can tell you that 95% of the employees did not respect or like him and had no confidence in his leadership. He is a very abrasive individual and constantly was offending the employees and management. My supervisor interviewed an individual that was related to John Hard and said she recommended them not to be hired and John Hard went and spoke with HR and convinced them to hire this individual which would appear to be the definition of nepotism. I would have reported this to HR but I did not witness it first hand and only heard it from my manager. \\A lot of this sounds very negative and that isn't my intent, I only bring up these points so that you may improve the culture of Vivint Solar. I really enjoyed working for Vivint Solar and gained a lot of experience and knowledge. It was an awesome job with interesting and challenging work. I would say the pros outweigh the cons and I would work at Vivint Solar again if I could make enough money to support my family working.  I would have never left, but I had to do what was best for myself and Family. \\Thank you for the opportunity to give my opinion, \\Shaun Oaks

For a sales organization, there is a disconnect in the fundamentals that encourage productivity and growth.  The unofficial company motto is "Lead from the front", which provides for strong completion, but should not be used as a basis for determining leaders.  It was evident in the stat sent to us all before a manager retreat that noted 50% of the installs 3rd quarter came from 15% of the sales staff.  That sales staff being the District Managers.  Sounds great, but that means 85% of your sales group is producing at a far great rate.  Vivint promotes and extends the pay of managers, who while leading the office in installs, have no time to mentor the core.  21 and above installs in a quarter requires a tremendous amount of personal work.  The reality is Vivint offices have DM's that sell and sales reps that suffer.  Turnover is high and the common feeling for those leaving is that Vivint didn't care.   I came into this position with 17 years of home improvement sale, with the last 4 years in solar sales management.  A manager should manage, not teach a door pitch and expect the reps to wing it from there.  Solar as simple as it seams is complex.  I can only speak for the NorCal district, but there is no current sales training process that expands to solar 101, sales psychology, time management, Vivint policy and procedure, even appearance and attire.  For 6 months I watched week after week, manager after manager dedicate their time to a door knocking pitch.  They have this dialed in and are successful in their approach, but know little about solar as a whole.  Only a few robots make a living this way.  Most place in a sink or swim environment succom to the stress and financial famine.  By the time I earned the trust of my office staff they were eager to learn and valued the time spent expanding their knowledge.  I even provided additional meeting days where I was available for team members to join me on a voluntary basis.  The reality is... a 5% override to actually manage, while the other two managers split the remaining 95% makes no sense for me.   \\There are many operations issues within Vivint as well.  Too much to detail, but the opportunity for improvement is huge.  The framework is there.   The man power is there.   The business strategy and decision making is lacking.  Hope this helps in some way.  Thank you again for the opportunity.
The ability to lead, coach, train and be compensated for it directly.

I was employed at Vivint two separate times and the second time I came back I was really bought in but after a month I realized my DM was out for himself, I couldn't reach him and he would never answer a question and when I did ask questions in person I was given answers that sounded good but we're not true. I worked with two newer sales reps and helped them both because I had prior experience at Vivint. I think a lot of the reps who leave Vivint are capable of being very successful but when they do not get support they leave. I was in the LI west office and sometimes we shared the meetings with the Nassau office and the two DM's (Tony and Chase) seemed to genuinely care about there reps but it was not like that in the office I was in, I have witnessed a lot of wrongdoing at Vivint including illegal behavior and I never understood why corporate never steps in to find out why. I always thought watching Chance Allred on VSLR tv and also meeting him in person that he was one of the most honest straight forward people I've ever met but and all of the support people I have worked with from Utah seemed to be an extension of Chance but at the LI west office it's a different story, I have met a lot of good people and made many friends during my time at Vivint and I still run into a lot of former employees and everyone has something negative to say but when you listen to the issues its not directed at Vivint corporate it's a few of the people who were deceptive, dishonest and most of all greedy. I know my opinion especially as a former employee does not matter but the reason I am passionate about all of this is because a lot of good things came from my time there and I was proud to be Vivint and I just do not understand why corporate never stepped in to find out and maybe even make some changes. I'm not bitter, the truth is I actually have given three referrals to an active rep and one was installed last week. I realize a good amount of what I wrote is not positive so I will end this with something positive that I really feel strongly about, the operations dept. in Westbury is ran by two people, Mike Mortenson and Georgi Dhima and they are what separates Vivint from the other Solar companies on Long Island and I have had a lot of experiences with them were they resolved issues and taught me a lot as well, Vivint really has two gems including the teams they run. Please feel free to contact me, but if I do not hear from you I want to wish you a happy holiday to everyone at corporate, a lot of which I've spoken to on the phone but have never met but really enjoyed working with.

The main issue I had was with being blocked from making the type and magnitude of impact I was hired to make (or what is typically expected of people in my profession).  I had good backing from my direct management in what I was doing, but I could not getting a foothold to make an impact in a couple major departments where most of the spend is coming from.  When roadblocks popped up there wasn't anyone there to help me clear the path.  With me being a Sr. Manager there is only so much I could do to influence Directors, VPs, and C-level execs.  Many times I felt that VSLR wanted more of a finance person who does purchasing on the side.  \\Compensation almost always plays a factor in deciding to leave a job or company.  VSLR is in a tough situation with finances being tight and I can understand some of the reasons why they may not compensate as well as other companies and why they may not pay bonuses or give raises.  There are disparities in compensation based on who you work for, who you are, etc.  In my experience and the experience of others I've spoken with on this subject, VSLR pays well below market compensation.  Once you are hired on at a certain rate you can't see more than a 10% increase for the most part.  A 2.5% or lower increase was more typical if a raise was given at all.  The only time I was able to get more than a 10% raise was when I had another job offer. Finances are tough and margins are thin in this industry, but it all just makes you feel a lot like a number to be managed down and less like a valuable employee who is fairly compensated for the position and the value you bring to the company.

Seeing the value of involving procurement in every aspect of the company regardless of culture, status quo, current management, etc\\Much better pay\\Career growth opportunities\\401K match!  I never understood why VSLR didn't offer this, it should be standard.  I heard once that it was a choice between free lunch and a match.  I as well as so many others would have taken a 401K match over lunch 100% of the time.\\Someone who is able and willing to clear the road blocks\\Not only better chances of getting a 100% bonus, but they also have a bonus multiplier that can get you 2X your full bonus\\Better health programs

I worked for Vivint Smart Home and Vivint Solar for 11.5 years and I loved it.  It was difficult for me to leave, but it was the best decision at the time. Paying me what I was promised. I was "moved" from a commission only sales rep position to the retail team doing lead generation and promised a weekly minimum bonus of $450 plus $150/lead. They told me in order to accept I had to commit 30 hours a week and encouraged me to quit my other job (where I made over $20/hr) and start monday. When I requested an updated contract they told me they were "waiting on paperwork" but assured me the program was already up and running and I would be paid.  So I worked 30 hrs a week plus 3 hours of commuting through LA traffic everyday for the entire month of December. I never received an updated contract and I was never paid ANYTHING.  When I contacted HR they told me there was never a promise of the weekly minimum (even though there was) and claimed that none of the 25+ leads I generated were payable. I lost my home and was forced to move back in with family after not making any money all month. I had a great job and Vivint said I would make twice as much then just wrecked my life and acted like nothing happened. I will be pursuing legal action if this is not remedied ASAP.

It’s unfortunate because solar is an amazing product to sell, even the Vivint offering was good, technical tools (iPad tools), amazing culture and community office. But the issues and problems have been overlooked and mismanaged by Vivint Solar Corp. I felt sick at times hearing some of the customers complaints about not getting help from talking to Vivint solar Corp. Operations and  processes have severely limited our ability to get permits submitted and jobs installed and make a steady income. Not having more team support (assistants to help manage progression of accounts) ultimately has made working for Vivint unenjoyable, toxic and very stressful. A clear example of this was whe we were part of this pilot program by Chrissy & Ahslei (they managed multiple DMs accounts for years) where they came in and helped managed our (teams) accounts progression to install after we sold a job. Overall job satisfaction increased, team productivity went up, more jobs went through and the timing of job sold to install was considerably faster. Unfortunately, Vivint Corp did not support that pilot program and things went back to how they were before. Shortly after many reps left, all those issues and ineffiences that existed prior came back and overall production went down. The pilot program showed clear evidence and results and promising new processes that solved all the ineffiencies we had as sales reps and as an office. It seemed that Vivint Corp was not willing to bankroll hiring team operational support and as a result the work environment went back to how things were. After realizing things weren’t going to change and the issues were met with apathy from Vivint HQ I realized it’s better to jump ship then try to polish the brass on the titanic. I don’t feel that people in Vivint HQ realize how diffiicult knocking doors and selling 20-50k contracts for solar really is in a loan markets  I feel there is a clear disconnect between upper management and the “foot soldiers.” It’s unfortunate as I had a lot of good memories and experiences with team.

Management is terrible at Vivint Solar. Training is seen by lower management as a hindrance to productivity. Internal communication is severely neglected. Designers are severely overworked. Upper management ignores the talent of lower employees that can help improve the company. This viewpoint is shared by managers in the engineering department. As a personal example, I've had three years of experience in quality in a heavily regulated industry, have taken classes on quality systems, and am a certified quality technician through the American Society of Quality. As a result, I was in a unique position to improve the company by incorporating an ISO-based quality system, but my suggestions were largely ignored, and those that were looked at were executed poorly or not understood. Being a quality technician and reviewing accounts and OA redesigns, I was able to see the response pattern to some issues, and the complete lack of it for others. Vivint Solar will never seriously improve their quality until upper management gets rid of their culture which only looks at talent and ideas from either upper management, those who rub elbows with them, or those who fit their idea of what management should look like. Engineers are notorious for pointing out flaws, especially quality engineers, which I've noticed is at odds with the salesperson culture of upper management. The biggest change that would have made me stay would be the change of the culture of upper management.
Training, communication, recognition, pay worth my education, and a significantly better culture from upper management.

I actually really enjoyed the job while I was just starting out scheduling installations, but I was informed in my second week that my position was turning into more of a customer service position as responsibilities were being redistributed among RTS. I was disappointed by this because I saw my coworkers struggling with calls they did not feel adequately trained for, and their efforts to receive more training were largely met with frustration from their leadership. I did not sign up for a customer service position, I signed up for a scheduling position, so I decided not to move forward. I also was frustrated when I spoke with my supervisor about reducing my hours (I was in a full-time position) and he said that unless I was going back to school or had a compelling reason I needed to do so, I would not be approved to do so. If I could have reduced my hours and stayed, and the position was still scheduling installations, I would have stayed. I really enjoyed the work environment and found my coworkers to be exceptionally friendly. I also really appreciated the opportunity to have easy access to free healthy meals each day. I think this company is great, but for several reasons, this job in particular was not a good fit for me.

The thing is, there aren't just one or two issues that would help employees want to stay. Very few of the management personel (whether lower, middle, or upper) seem to really care about their subordinates. Commands and mandates are thrown down with little to no real communication on what the goal is, or (more often) how to achieve it. The upper management lies and uses deceptive wording to keep the masses under control and willing to work. When a plan is laid out and prepared for, the 'leadership' changes the whole plan at the last minute, and expects everyone to just figure out how to make it work. There are promises of raises and promotions thrown out all the time, but there's almost always some feeble excuse to not follow through with them. Instead, workers just get more and more duties with no extra compensation. The workers take on the extra work, with the hope of getting recognized for their extra work and given promotions or raises. But since the workers are taking it without complaint, the leadership sees no reason to give out extra compensation. Why pay more when you don't have to? So the extra work becomes the expected normal workload, and the whole cycle starts over again. Lower level employees are not valued in the slightest bit. There is next to no attempt made toward employee retention. There are plenty of other college-age kids here, who are desperate for a job, right? When upper leadership refers to their employees as "the equivalent of burger flippers", there's clearly a problem. None of the executives seem to care, and those who might don't know because the ones causing the majority of the problems (Evan Pack) are making it look like everything is just hunky dory.\Bottom line: in order to significantly increase employee retention beyond a year, major changes in pay, communication, processes/policies and overall leadership have to occur. But I'm more than confident that none of those necessary changes will happen. Vivint Solar is a sinking ship, with its sails aflame.
Better pay, better benefits, better communication, better work environment, better equipment, better leadership, and FAR more respect.

For starters I didn’t quit or choose to leave Vivint. I was in the ADA interactive process and received no communication that I was about to be terminated. I have been receiving medical treatment for ulnar neuropathy and cervicogenic headaches since November. I told my managers on more than one occasion that I was dealing with severe headaches that affected my ability to work and I was never given any options to talk to HR. The work culture itself was a cesspool of toxic masculinity. Rather than use meetings to discuss specific deals or give us analyicsl tools to manage our work, we played baseball in the parking lot, forced to participate in a pushup contest, and subjected to inspirational videos by Navy SEALs. Those kinds of things created a hostile work environment wherein any effort to get meaningful assistance from the managers ended with the solution of simply getting more new accounts and often questioning my work ethic. I worked at Countrywide yesrs ago and those managers were there to help new hires close deals. The managers in my office were great at sales but were not helpful at all when it came to second voicing customers. The manner in which Nick Hansen tried to fire me in October was disgusting and I would like to talk to someone about it. I was getting no salary and my dog was dying and he tried to turn my firing into this thing where he was doing me a favor. During that conversation he tried to fet me to agree to things that were simply false, such as the date of my hire and the number of accounts I had created. From the start Nick was unhelpful and simply focused on enthusiasm for the company rather than helping me and others advance accounts. He was also nowhere to be found for much of the time while I was there because of a new baby. \\In general I would have eliminated the pep rally meetings entirely and keep the office open at all times so we could go in there and work on accounts with an experienced manager. The fact that it is 2018 and we couldn’t use salesforce to manage customers is simply unbelievable. The emphasis on sales games, video productions, and groupme is a total waste of time. It is like lighting time on fire and watching it burn. I do not need motivation to make money. I am not inspired by cheesy videos of coworkers. The groupme activity is a lawsuit waiting to happen. Making money is about being efficient and leveraging technology to make work easier. Making money is not done by ignoring awful conversion rates and organizational tools that improve efficiency on the margin. Exhorting sales staff to generate leads that can then be worked on by internal sales teams after the original staff member leaves is a cynical way to do business even though it is probably very profitable. \\In short I feel that my time at Vivint was wasted due to the fact that I had a tremendous amount of success getting new accounts and got zero support. Getting documents and consent is not easy. I was good at it and instead of helping me close deals I only got grief over ACs. I believe that residential solar can greatly improve household finances for most ratepayers and will always be disappointed by my lack of success at Vivint. That being said I believe the work culture needs to lose the Amway/Herbalife mindset. The competitive games destroy incentives to cooperate at the office level and just imagine the returns if Vivint spent that weekly video production budget on technology. I would very much like to have a exit interview in person and believe that Vivint should have offered me a job that accomodated my health situation before terminating my employment. My phone number is 312-485-9241.
There was a lot of potential with this job but the work culture ignores efficiency at best and is ableist at worst.

Vivent should only have jobs scheduled from 8-3 or so because of travel time to first job and jobs not getting enough time to finish within the given amount. Tesla only pays electricians $35-$39 an hour but because it's a better environment, electricians stay there instead of going to Vivint. I only left Tesla because I was in N.H. and the N.H. shop didn't have enough work so I had to leave. In my territory, electricity prices were very close to Vivint’s rates, within 1 cent/kWh for PPA, and for the loan, the monthly cost was 1.5-2x the average electric bill.  For a product that has very limited exposure (which in my territory it does), potential customers were very hesitant to make a 20-year deal which, due to the 2.9% annual increase and PECO rates which had actually shown stability - if not decline - over the past 2 years, could very possibly cost them more money. \All of the success stories I heard were of salesmen who were in territories that had at least 1 of 2 things:\1) a rate that was significantly below the electric rate (min 20%); and/or \2) high SRECs (like in NJ).\In the end, the product itself (at least in my territory) was not enough for customers to switch.
